DUTIES OF OFFICERS

Page

Table of Contents

 

Victoria

 

Victorian WHS laws do not prescribe the same categories of offences as other states. However, they clearly distinguish between reckless breaches, non-reckless breaches and breaches that do not pose a risk of serious harm or death. Users in Victoria should still note the differences in the seriousness of Category 1, 2 and 3 offences.

 

Officers in Victoria can only be liable for the maximum fine applicable to individuals for that particular breach.

 

Victoria

If an officer of a PCBU fails to exercise due diligence to ensure a PCBU does not breach its WHS duties, a court can impose a range of penalties depending on the seriousness of the offence committed.

 

Click on each category of offence for more details

 

Category 1 offence

 

Requirements of the PCBU

 

The PCBU:

 

•

owes a health and safety duty

•

engages in conduct that exposes an individual (to whom that duty is owed) to a risk of death, serious injury or illness, whether or not death or injury actually occurs

•

is reckless to the risk of death, serious injury or illness from their conduct

 

Maximum penalty for officers

 

$600,000 and/or five years' imprisonment

 

Category 2 offence

 

Requirements of the PCBU

 

The PCBU:

 

•

owes a health and safety duty

•

fails to comply with that duty

•

exposes an individual to a risk of death, serious injury or serious illness

 

Maximum penalty for officers

 

$300,000

 

 

Category 3 offence

Requirements of the PCBU

 

The PCBU:

 

•

owes a health and safety duty

•

fails to comply with that duty

Maximum penalty for officers

 

$100,000
